desc: The MST1 (mammalian sterile 20-like kinase 1) gene encodes a kinase and key component of the Hippo signaling pathway. The Hippo signaling cascade is a critical regulator for controlling cell growth, differentiation and organ size control (PMID: 22683405, 22898666). MST1 is proteolyticaly activated by caspases during apoptosis; activation is mediated by apoptotic stimuli and other stress signals. Full activation of MST1 kinase requires autophosphorylation at Thr-183 and caspase-mediated cleavage. Once activated, MST1 phosphorylates Lats1/2 (large tumor suppressor 1/2), which then phosphorylates and inhibits two transcriptional coactivators in the Hippo pathway, YAP and TAZ (PMID:17889654). Phosphorylated YAP and TAZ remain in the cytoplasm and cannot induce the expression of genes that promote cell growth and proliferation (PMID: 17889654). Hence, MST1 negatively regulates YAP and TAZ and acts as a tumor suppressor. Reduced expression of MST1 has been observed in gastric cancer, liver cancer, prostate cancer and soft tissue sarcoma (PMID: 21940329, 17538946, 18381433).

desc: MST1 encodes a serine/threonine kinase involved in inhibiting proliferation and promoting apoptosis.
